pull.title: feefrac: 128-bit multiply support in MSVC
pull.body:
Feerate comparisons in the recently (#29242) introduced `FeeFrac` type rely on multiplications between 32-bit and 64-bit integers. On 64-bit systems, hardware can do this natively. On GCC and Clang we can use the `__int128` type for this, but on MSVC one needs to use the `_mul128` or `_mulh` intrinsics instead. This PR adds these.

I have not tested this code myself, though it's based on similar code in libsecp256k1 (see https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/v0.4.1/src/int128_struct_impl.h#L7L30).

If your review is incorrectly listed, please react with 👎 to this comment and the bot will ignore it on the next update.
Hmm, does our CI not run the fuzz corpus when building with MSVC?

> Hmm, does our CI not run the fuzz corpus when building with MSVC?

Afaik it does not but it would probably make sense. We also do it in the MacOS job.

> Hmm, does our CI not run the fuzz corpus when building with MSVC?

No, it does not. Even a fuzz binary is not built.
I think it would be very useful if we did. Fuzzing itself won't work in MSVC, but I don't think there is a technical reason why we can't run the existing fuzz corpus.

issue.title: build: Enable Fuzz binary in MSVC
issue.body:
This should be enough to iterate over the existing fuzz inputs in the CI

Suggested by @sipa in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/29758#issuecomment-2025593572

events.message: feefrac: add some more unit tests

comments.body: We do not explicitly support ARM64 for Windows. But it won't hurt, and is good for completeness.
Oh if that's not tested anywhere I should probably remove it. There would be no way to catch mistakes in it.
Yes, we have no tests for MSVC builds on ARM64.
I've dropped the ARM64 code, and added some more unit tests.
